repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
With the welcomed demise of `netrw`, we lost an opportunity to use an arbitrary command for opening URL-like strings with `gx`. This should suggest a way how to recover this functionality.

Of course, new name of the variable `vim.g.netrw_browsex_viewer` should be developed (I am not sure what are the standards for creating new options).

Another thing which is missing are tests. I tried to create one, but I got completely lost and frankly `neovim` is not my primary editor, so I don’t have a time to dive too deep into its innards.

Will eventually Fix: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/29488

comment_data.body:
`vim.fn.executable()` will error with a `nil` argument.

```suggestion
  if vim.g.netrw_browsex_viewer and vim.fn.executable(vim.g.netrw_browsex_viewer) == 1 then
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -141,7 +141,9 @@ function M.open(path)
 
   local cmd --- @type string[]
 
-  if vim.fn.has('mac') == 1 then
+  if vim.fn.executable(vim.g.netrw_browsex_viewer) == 1 then

comment_data.body:
My preference would be to leave support for this `netrw` variable undocumented (we can silently support it to make people transitioning from netrw easier).

If we want to document another way to do this, I'd prefer using a different name for this variable. Perhaps this could even be a variable in the `vim.ui` module/namespace (e.g. `vim.ui.opener = 'foobar'`). Though ultimately this seems like something that would go into `vim.ui.config()` https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/25514.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2555,6 +2555,9 @@ vim.ui.open({path})                                            *vim.ui.open()*
     `explorer.exe`, Linux `xdg-open`, …), or returns (but does not show) an
     error message on failure.
 
+    Instead of the system default handler the function calls a command set in
+    the 'vim.g.netrw_browsex_viewer', if it is present.
+

comment_data.body:
Yes, not documenting it is one way, but I expected (and I mentioned it above) that some new name more in line with the standard Neovim naming conventions would be suggested.

Also, I don’t think #25514 is relevant here. Surprisingly, there is almost no visible Neovim UI touched, it is just one shortcut and a signal which Neovim sends to the system.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2555,6 +2555,9 @@ vim.ui.open({path})                                            *vim.ui.open()*
     `explorer.exe`, Linux `xdg-open`, …), or returns (but does not show) an
     error message on failure.
 
+    Instead of the system default handler the function calls a command set in
+    the 'vim.g.netrw_browsex_viewer', if it is present.
+

comment_data.body: let's keep this here and name the parameter `cmdpath`, for now (open to better names). we generally avoid changing the type of a variable in the middle of a codepath
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -139,12 +145,16 @@ function M.open(path)
     path = vim.fs.normalize(path)
   end
 
-  local cmd --- @type string[]

comment_data.body: similar to `:help vim.paste` we could mention here how to override `vim.ui.open` to bind `cmd` to the user's preference.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -109,6 +109,9 @@ end
 --- Opens `path` with the system default handler (macOS `open`, Windows `explorer.exe`, Linux
 --- `xdg-open`, …), or returns (but does not show) an error message on failure.
 ---
+--- Instead of the system default handler the function calls a command set in
+--- the 'cmd' optional parameter.

comment_data.body: is `osurl` something we should add as a fallback to the builtin impl?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -117,6 +120,8 @@ end
 --- -- Asynchronous.
 --- vim.ui.open("https://neovim.io/")
 --- vim.ui.open("~/path/to/file")
+--- -- Command 'osurl' knows what to do with this reference
+--- vim.ui.open("gh#neovim/neovim!29490", "osurl")

comment_data.body: No, it is just [my script](https://git.sr.ht/~mcepl/vim-suse-changes/tree/master/item/osurl) which handles [SUSE abbreviated URLs](https://en.opensuse.org/openSUSE:Packaging_Patches_guidelines#Current_set_of_abbreviations). It is meant just as an example of a random script (and obviously this abbreviation is the reference to this PR). That’s the point of this whole PR, that one can use their custom script for handling URLs/Paths.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -117,6 +120,8 @@ end
 --- -- Asynchronous.
 --- vim.ui.open("https://neovim.io/")
 --- vim.ui.open("~/path/to/file")
+--- -- Command 'osurl' knows what to do with this reference
+--- vim.ui.open("gh#neovim/neovim!29490", "osurl")

comment_data.body: Apparently, I am doing [something wrong here](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/actions/runs/10635265306/job/29484474827?pr=29490#step:5:157), but I don’t understand what.
`|vim.ui.open|` should be `|vim.ui.open()|`, `'gx'` should be `|gx|` and `cmdpath` doesn't even seem to exist.

don't need to mention "optional" in the docstring, just use the `?` syntax. Also would you mind changing this to a `opts` style param (`:help kwargs`). 

Then this PR should be good to go. I have a followup here (I'll rebase it after merging this one): https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/30271

```suggestion
---@param opts? table If given, `opts.cmd` will be tried first.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -125,12 +127,15 @@ end
 --- ```
 ---
 ---@param path string Path or URL to open
+---@param cmdpath string|string[] optional command to be used for opening URL

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
--- -- Use the "osurl" command to handle the path or URL.
--- vim.ui.open("gh#neovim/neovim!29490", { cmd = { 'osurl' } })
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -117,6 +117,8 @@ end
 --- -- Asynchronous.
 --- vim.ui.open("https://neovim.io/")
 --- vim.ui.open("~/path/to/file")
+--- -- Command 'osurl' knows what to do with this reference
+--- vim.ui.open("gh#neovim/neovim!29490", "osurl")

comment_data.body:
if cmdpath is a list then this won't work. rather than supporting `string|string[]`, let's require `string[]`.

```suggestion
    cmd = vim.list_extend(cmdpath, { path })
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -139,12 +144,17 @@ function M.open(path)
     path = vim.fs.normalize(path)
   end
 
-  local cmd --- @type string[]
+  local cmd --- @type string[]|string[][]
   local opts --- @type vim.SystemOpts
 
   opts = { text = true, detach = true }
 
-  if vim.fn.has('mac') == 1 then
+  if cmdpath then
+    -- not checking for the existence of the cmd command, because
+    -- it could be a more complicated string or even list of
+    -- string, not just the name of the executable
+    cmd = { cmdpath, path }

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
  local cmd --- @type string[]
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -139,12 +144,17 @@ function M.open(path)
     path = vim.fs.normalize(path)
   end
 
-  local cmd --- @type string[]
+  local cmd --- @type string[]|string[][]

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
• |vim.ui.open()| (by default bound to |gx|) accepts an optional `opts.cmd`
  parameter which will be tried before falling back to other default tools.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -188,7 +188,10 @@ TUI
 
 UI
 
-• TODO
+• Behaviour of the function |vim.ui.open()| (by default bound to |gx| key
+  shortcut) can now be configured by setting the its second optional parameter
+  `cmdpath` to the name of the command which should be run with the selected
+  string as the only parameter.

comment_data.body: OK, I am not sure if I understand here: does it mean you are rejecting my idea of single parameter `cmdpath` and require adding optional `opts` parameter with a possible attribute `cmd`?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -125,12 +127,15 @@ end
 --- ```
 ---
 ---@param path string Path or URL to open
+---@param cmdpath string|string[] optional command to be used for opening URL

comment_data.body: "rejecting your idea" sounds harsh. we need an `opts` parameter, and its first field will be `opts.cmd`. that's equivalent, except we just need to think about future extensibility (see my other PR), so an `opts` parameter is appropriate
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -125,12 +127,15 @@ end
 --- ```
 ---
 ---@param path string Path or URL to open
+---@param cmdpath string|string[] optional command to be used for opening URL

comment_data.body:
I don’t care about harsh, we are engineers and what matters is the result, if your suggestions make the result better, then they should be accepted. And they do.

(And yes, I live too close to Germany, and in these parts, we don’t pussyfoot about something being wrong, we just say it).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -125,12 +127,15 @@ end
 --- ```
 ---
 ---@param path string Path or URL to open
+---@param cmdpath string|string[] optional command to be used for opening URL

comment_data.body:
single quotes in vim help files link to vim options
```suggestion
---           to handle `path` as its last command argument.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -125,12 +127,16 @@ end
 --- ```
 ---
 ---@param path string Path or URL to open
+---@param opts? table Additional options
+---     - cmd (string[]|string)
+---           Alternative URL handler: if set, editor will use this command
+---           to handle 'path' as its only command argument.

comment_data.body: looks like `opts` and `conf` are being mixed up. they aren't related. this should just be `opts.cmd`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -140,11 +146,15 @@ function M.open(path)
   end
 
   local cmd --- @type string[]
-  local opts --- @type vim.SystemOpts
+  local conf --- @type vim.SystemOpts
 
-  opts = { text = true, detach = true }
+  conf = opts or {}
+  conf.text = opts.text or true
+  conf.detach = opts.detach or true
 
-  if vim.fn.has('mac') == 1 then
+  if conf.cmd then
+    cmd = vim.list_extend(conf.cmd, { path })

comment_data.body: looks like `opts` and `conf` are being mixed up. they aren't related.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -140,11 +146,15 @@ function M.open(path)
   end
 
   local cmd --- @type string[]
-  local opts --- @type vim.SystemOpts
+  local conf --- @type vim.SystemOpts
 
-  opts = { text = true, detach = true }
+  conf = opts or {}
+  conf.text = opts.text or true
+  conf.detach = opts.detach or true

comment_data.body: Well, `opts` is the function argument, whereas `conf` is the function internal variable. I could (probably) replace the first line with `opts = opts or {}`, but then the next two lines would fail, and these two parameters would be essentially hard coded (do we want that?).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -140,11 +146,15 @@ function M.open(path)
   end
 
   local cmd --- @type string[]
-  local opts --- @type vim.SystemOpts
+  local conf --- @type vim.SystemOpts
 
-  opts = { text = true, detach = true }
+  conf = opts or {}
+  conf.text = opts.text or true
+  conf.detach = opts.detach or true

comment_data.body: see above
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -140,11 +146,15 @@ function M.open(path)
   end
 
   local cmd --- @type string[]
-  local opts --- @type vim.SystemOpts
+  local conf --- @type vim.SystemOpts
 
-  opts = { text = true, detach = true }
+  conf = opts or {}
+  conf.text = opts.text or true
+  conf.detach = opts.detach or true
 
-  if vim.fn.has('mac') == 1 then
+  if conf.cmd then
+    cmd = vim.list_extend(conf.cmd, { path })

comment_data.body: i guess `opts` could be a way to pass these options, but it wasn't really something we discussed, and it's not documented... should wait until a different PR so we can wrap this one up
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -140,11 +146,15 @@ function M.open(path)
   end
 
   local cmd --- @type string[]
-  local opts --- @type vim.SystemOpts
+  local conf --- @type vim.SystemOpts
 
-  opts = { text = true, detach = true }
+  conf = opts or {}
+  conf.text = opts.text or true
+  conf.detach = opts.detach or true

comment_data.body: Ehm, can I ask for your suggestion here? I really don’t understand what would you like to be done.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -140,11 +146,15 @@ function M.open(path)
   end
 
   local cmd --- @type string[]
-  local opts --- @type vim.SystemOpts
+  local conf --- @type vim.SystemOpts
 
-  opts = { text = true, detach = true }
+  conf = opts or {}
+  conf.text = opts.text or true
+  conf.detach = opts.detach or true

comment_regular_data.body: I have no idea what’s the `docs / docs` test problem.

This seems like another eventual candidate for `vim.ui.config()`: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/25514

In the meantime though, supporting this variable for backwards compatibility seems fine to me. Although I am not sure that we should document it (we don't want _new_ code to start using this `netrw` variable).

cc @justinmk

On Sun Sep 1, 2024 at 2:01 PM CEST, dundargoc wrote:
> `|vim.ui.open|` should be `|vim.ui.open()|`, `'gx'` should be `|gx|` and `cmdpath` doesn't even seem to exist.

`cmdpath` is the new optional parameter of `vim.ui.open()` function.

title: feat(vim.ui.open): configurable opener
